Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Abacus: A New State-of-the-Art Cosmological N-body Code
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will further the development of a new computer code for cosmological N-body simulations. Abacus implements a novel method for computing gravitational forces that is a hundred times faster and substantially more accurate than current methods. It can be run on commodity graphics processing units and offers a vast improvement in price-performance. Observational surveys of large scale structure rely on cosmological simulations to calibrate their statistical estimators and compute accurate error bars, making it essential to run large grids of highly accurate simulations in order to realize the potential of current and future cosmological surveys. Abacus relies on a mathematical breakthrough that accomplishes a clean split between the near-field and far-field force on particles. The present work will add essential support for individual particle time steps, on-the-fly group finding and merger tree building, and light-cone outputs. The study will also extend Abacus to a parallel implementation, and allow release of a public version of the code.

The research team will use Abacus for a first suite of large simulations, whose resulting halo catalogs, merger trees, and light-cone outputs will be made public as a direct benefit to current and future survey projects. Abacus is a game-changer, opening up the ability to do large simulations to many more astrophysicists at exactly the time that the need for large sets of large simulations will intensify. The mathematical approach of Abacus opens up substantial new possibilities in the solution of elliptic equations, one of the most common computational tasks across a wide range of scientific and engineering disciplines. Along the way, the project will train a post-doctoral researcher and a graduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Modern cosmology posits that the early Universe was smooth and almost featureless, yet the Universe
evolved into a highly-structured state with galaxies, clusters of galaxies, and even larger
structures. Gravity is the only force which can act at such large scales, and so the question
arises: how does gravity, acting over cosmic time and competing with the expansion of the Universe
caused by Dark Energy, cause the Universe to proceed from a nearly uniform to a highly structured
state?

The equations which describe the competition between gravitational clustering and cosmic expansion
are fairly simple. Their solutions, however, exhibit a rich structure which can only be explored in
detail by numerical simulation. Points of mass are set up in the computer in a nearly-uniform
state. The acceleration each particle experiences due to the attraction of all the others is then
computed. The points are moved under this influence, and the process is repeated, eventually
simulating virtually the entire history of the Universe.

Some of these simulations are among the largest computations in the world, resolving the entire
observable Universe with up to a trillion mass points. This high resolution is necessary to confront
the simulations with detailed observational data coming from all-sky surveys like LSST, DES, SDSS,
and WFIRST. Further, these simulations must be run many times to test out different theories of Dark
Energy. To date, such simulations have required the use of some of the world's largest
supercomputers.

To address this computational challenge, we have developed a number of novel mathematical and
computational approaches to simulating the gravitational interaction among very large numbers of
points. We have incorporated these developments into the simulation code Abacus. Abacus is more than
30 times faster than other codes, yet it simultaneously provides much higher accuracy solutions than
previously obtained. Exploiting developments in commodity computer hardware, it does not require a
supercomputer to do this, resulting in orders of magnitude improvement in price/performance. Abacus,
and the techniques it embodies, will enable many more, higher-accuracy simulations to be performed
than previously possible. It will also bring the capability to work in this field to researchers who
may not have access to large, high-performance computing facilities.

Remarkably, the equations describing the gravitational interactions between galaxies in the Universe
are of the same form as those describing the interactions between atoms and molecules. The
techniques we have developed for simulating the Universe can thus be directly applied to
computational chemistry, speeding up the calculations involved, for example, in designing chemical
processes and drugs.
